channel.title: Comments on: Using Multiple jQuery UI Sliders on a Single Page
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Alex Ullrich
item.dc:creator: Alex Ullrich
item.description: I don't think you'd want to "call" the slider to get its underlying value but there might be a way to get there. This is a hard question to answer without knowing how your system is structured though. Without knowing what your code looks like, the easiest thing that comes to mind is watching for changes on the form input backing the slider and using that to propagate your changes elsewhere. Maybe have a look here: https://api.jquery.com/change/
item.content:encoded: I don’t think you’d want to “call” the slider to get its underlying value but there might be a way to get there. This is a hard question to answer without knowing how your system is structured though. Without knowing what your code looks like, the easiest thing that comes to mind is watching for changes on the form input backing the slider and using that to propagate your changes elsewhere. Maybe have a look here: https://api.jquery.com/change/

item.title: By: JP
item.dc:creator: JP
item.description: Greetings Alex, thank you for the code! Forgive my being a novice, but how do you call the slider value? Your example does present it at the top of each slider, how would I call or refer to that value say if I wanted to display it somewhere else as well?
item.content:encoded: Greetings Alex, thank you for the code! Forgive my being a novice, but how do you call the slider value? Your example does present it at the top of each slider, how would I call or refer to that value say if I wanted to display it somewhere else as well?

item.title: By: Alex Ullrich
item.dc:creator: Alex Ullrich
item.description: Do you mean $(this)? I haven't done anything with the stop function but don't see why it wouldn't work. These examples could be way out of date by now though.
item.content:encoded: Do you mean $(this)? I haven’t done anything with the stop function but don’t see why it wouldn’t work. These examples could be way out of date by now though.

item.title: By: David
item.dc:creator: David
item.description: Okay, so what I mean is I added to each slider a data-whatever and I try to read that in for an ajax update on the fly on slider changes. But at adding the "stop" function to the slider's js, with the appropriate code, $this comes back as undefined, when it should be able to handle the actually clicked on slider no? Appreciated :)
item.content:encoded: Okay, so what I mean is I added to each slider a data-whatever and I try to read that in for an ajax update on the fly on slider changes. But at adding the “stop” function to the slider’s js, with the appropriate code, $this comes back as undefined, when it should be able to handle the actually clicked on slider no? Appreciated ðŸ™‚

item.title: By: David
item.dc:creator: David
item.description: Calling $this on a "stop:" function gives undefined, can that be rectified somehow?
item.content:encoded: Calling $this on a “stop:” function gives undefined, can that be rectified somehow?

item.title: By: Aniket
item.dc:creator: Aniket
item.content:encoded:
Hi,

Thanks for the code. Is it possible to display a label instead of the value? eg: When I slide to 4, it should display Good instead of 4.

item.title: By: Alex Ullrich
item.dc:creator: Alex Ullrich
item.description: Hey Nick - I just uploaded a quick demo. Glad you were able to get it working without, but hopefully it'll help others out.
item.content:encoded: Hey Nick – I just uploaded a quick demo. Glad you were able to get it working without, but hopefully it’ll help others out.

item.title: By: Alex Ullrich
item.dc:creator: Alex Ullrich
item.description: Nick, that is my fault - I removed a bit of code to make the demo easier and forgot to remove that piece (I needed to read the initial value of the slider from the corresponding input). I'll try to throw a simple demo together and attach it to the post.
item.content:encoded: Nick, that is my fault – I removed a bit of code to make the demo easier and forgot to remove that piece (I needed to read the initial value of the slider from the corresponding input). I’ll try to throw a simple demo together and attach it to the post.

item.title: By: Nick Blexrud
item.dc:creator: Nick Blexrud
item.content:encoded:
Perfect! Although, I don’t see how you would need the value: val?

I was able to use it without.
